column183: The battle over President Park Geun-hye’s proposals to liberalize South Korea’s labor laws is intensifying
column184: with subway and railway workers jointly striking last month for the first time in nearly two decades
column185: Since the current legislature is determined to block Ms
column187: the militant resistance may seem odd
column188: But the unions are right to be nervous
column189: Their influence has waned as public awareness of the need for labor reform has grown
column190: When Korea elects its next President in a little more than a year
column191: the new administration’s agenda will almost certainly include moves to grant companies greater freedom to hire and fire
column193: Park started this debate with a push for legal changes to the use of
column195: who do not receive full benefits and protections against dismissal
column197: companies rely on such workers to get around labor laws that make it virtually impossible to lay off full-time employees
column198: Korean companies are currently required to transfer irregular workers to permanent status after two years
column199: The Park reforms would double this to four years for workers older than 35
column200: while expanding the list of businesses that can employ irregular workers. Currently Korea’s flagship heavy manufacturing and shipping industries are restricted to full employees
column201: hampering competitiveness.The South Korean economy has been sluggish for the past five years
column202: due in part to the inflexible labor market
column203: The country is also experiencing some of its highest youth-unemployment rates on record
column205: Japan and Europe demonstrate how a rigid labor market hits the young hardest because companies are reluctant to take risks hiring inexperienced workers they will be unable to fire
column207: Park’s reform proposals were blocked in the National Assembly last year even though her Saenuri party had a majority
column208: April’s election saw Saenuri lose control and the opposition is even more determined to deprive the President of a victory
column209: But while the opposing Minjoo Party and People’s Party are aligned with the unions
column210: neither party is fundamentally opposed to reforms
column211: and both are likely to propose their own variations on labor reform as the December 2017 presidential election draws near
column213: Park likely won’t pass labor reform during her tenure
column214: but she deserves credit for setting it in motion
column215: South Koreans don’t want to become the next Japan
column216: Meaningful labor reforms will be key to avoiding that fate
